evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed: 1) Social anxiety in academic settings and career uncertainty; 2) Solutions: Scripted peer approaches, email templates for networking, gum/breathing techniques, and Exposure Lite™ practice; 3) Sarah responded positively: Practiced dialogues, created mint-offer strategy, prepared TA scripts, and scheduled library study; 4) Progress evidence: Contributed in study group without freezing, developed concrete coping tools (emergency mints, color-coded notes), and demonstrated self-awareness by reframing nervousness humorously.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems: Career uncertainty, social anxiety in academic settings, fear of rejection when initiating conversations, and presentation/question-asking anxiety. 2) Solutions: Scripted social approaches, email templates for networking, physical grounding techniques, and reframing questions as material-focused. 3) Response: Sarah actively practiced scripts, created implementation plans (calendar alerts, prepared contacts), and adopted coping strategies (gum, breathing). 4) Progress: Successfully participated in study group, developed concrete action plans, recognized irrational thoughts, and demonstrated improved self-advocacy by asking for help. Anxiety decreased from 8 to 7.5 due to acquired tools and successful practice.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) PROBLEMS: Social anxiety in academic settings (initiating conversation, fear of rejection), career path uncertainty, and overthinking interactions. 2) SOLUTIONS: Coach offered contextual openers ('How'd you approach problem 3?'), email templates for career outreach, physical grounding techniques (wrist pulse + breaths), mint gum as anxiety tool, and role-play practice. 3) STUDENT RESPONSE: Sarah actively engaged in solutions - created scripts ('Hey I'm Sarah...'), practiced delivery, identified specific targets (smiling classmate, mint-carrying peer), and accepted incremental challenges (coffee shop mint offer). 4) PROGRESS EVIDENCE: Demonstrated self-awareness by recognizing cognitive distortions; translated math comfort to coping strategy; prepared digital/physical tools (contacts app, gum pack); successfully role-played recovery from awkward moments; planned concrete next steps with time/location specificity.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems discussed: Social anxiety preventing peer connections (specifically in calculus group), career path uncertainty, and presentation/TA interaction fears. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Mint-sharing icebreaker, 3-breath pulse technique, scripting interactions, email outreach to upperclassmen, and color-coded panic plans. 3) Student's response: Actively co-created solutions (e.g., adapting math logic to breathing, selecting Wednesday library timing), practiced scripts repeatedly, and committed to specific actions. 4) Evidence of progress: Demonstrated improved self-awareness (identifying friendly classmate), successfully explained problem in study group, developed concrete implementation plans (mint offer, TA script), and reduced self-criticism (reframing 'awkward' moments as relatable).

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed: 1) Social avoidance in academic settings, 2) Career path uncertainty, 3) Physical anxiety symptoms during interactions. Solutions offered/accepted: Role-played conversation starters, email outreach to upperclassmen, physical grounding techniques (pulse check + breathing), and 'oops recovery' phrases. Student responded positively: Developed personalized scripts, practiced mint-offering approach, scheduled calculus group attempt, and emailed TA. Evidence of progress: Shifted from passive worry to active planning, created anxiety toolkit, identified math passion as social bridge, and demonstrated improved self-awareness through strategy customization.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed: 1) Social anxiety in academic settings (initiating conversations, fear of awkwardness), 2) Career path uncertainty regarding math major, and 3) Physical panic responses. Solutions offered/accepted: Role-playing specific interactions (mint offering, study invites), email templates for upperclassmen outreach, physiological grounding techniques (wrist pulse + breathing), and structured exposure plans (coffee shop attempt, TA question). Student responded positively: Created color-coded scripts, practiced interactions 5x, scheduled concrete attempts (Thursday coffee/TA), and adopted recovery phrases ("Classic me!"). Evidence of progress: Shifted from paralysis to actionable plans, developed personalized coping tools (mint strategy), recognized cognitive distortions, and demonstrated problem-solving by adapting solutions (e.g., replacing networking events with targeted emails).

Discussed 1) Social avoidance in calculus group, 2) Career path uncertainty, and 3) TA interaction fears. Solutions included: a) Post-class mint-offering strategy, b) Scripted email for upperclassmen, c) Color-coded TA approach plan with 'disaster exits'. Sarah responded positively by: creating detailed scripts, practicing with role-play, and implementing the coffee shop trial. Evidence of improvement includes: successful barista interaction, self-designed 'Exposure Lite™' framework for TA approach, and reframing anxiety as manageable ('one problem at a time'). Demonstrated behavioral shift from avoidance to strategic attempts with safety protocols.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems: Social anxiety (class interactions, TA approach), career uncertainty, and overthinking paralysis. 2) Solutions: Graduated exposure plans (barista->classmate->TA), scripted openers, physical grounding (pulse check), and reframing techniques. 3) Student response: Actively co-created strategies (mint approach), practiced role-plays, scheduled accountability check-ins, and adapted solutions (color-coded panic script). 4) Progress evidence: Successfully executed coffee shop interaction, developed personalized study group approach plan, demonstrated improved self-awareness ('still nervous but have tools'), and shifted perspective on failure (sparkly data collection).
